messages.subject: Re: Interesting sword
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Thank you for your imput!  My first thought was also the possibility of a well preserved nakago.  As far as determining if it is ubu or o-suriage
messages.messageBody:
Ron,

Thank you for your imput! My first thought was also the possibility of
a well preserved nakago. As far as determining if it is ubu or
o-suriage unfortunately exceeds my expertise. I've taken a few photos
and will post them as soon as possible. I was unable to capture all
aspects of my description in the pictures, but hopefully they will help.
The sori is 1.5 cm and is tori. The blade as mentioned is a bit "
rough" but is overall healthy. I detect no "drop off " running my
thumb and fore finger through the machi area. Possibly another clue to
a later blade??

Thanks again,

Dave
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...> wrote:
>
> Ricky -
>
> >The hada is very prominant, it seems to be a Itame/Mokume mix with
Masame near the ha. The Masame hada also can be >clearly seen through
the kissaki...O-sugikai yasurime...suguha...
>
> All of this makes me think ko-to and not at all shinshin-to work. I
wonder if your sword's nakago is simply well preserved, making you think
it is "newer" than it really is. Anytime I see a masame running along
the ha it makes me think "early" and starts me looking for further
clues. The sword is relatively short; is the nakago original (ubu) or
could it be O-suriage? The mention of O-sugikai yasurime makes me think
it is ubu, unsigned. It still makes me think ko-to with Yamato
characteristic; sue-Tegai perhaps? You do not mention sori; I'm curious
what this is telling you. Any photos available???
>
> Ron
> STL
>
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: dwmac2000
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Monday, November 13, 2006 11:59 PM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Interesting sword
>
>

>
> Definitely appreciate the information! I will research your

> seems to have a hada simular to koto Yamato Taima and Shikkake both.
> Sure wish the nakago appeared 500 yrs. older. None the less, still a
> good research project.
>
> Thanks Again,
>
> Dave

> >
> > Lots of possibilites based on your description. Off the top of a
> > newbie's head: Naminohira, Kunikane, outside possibility of Gassan
> > if you happen to see any spots of ayasugi hada. Hope this points you
> > in the right direction.
> >
> > Ricky
> >
> >
> > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "dwmac2000" dwmac2000@
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello, Recently purchased a sword which was in a closet wrapped
> > in a
> > > blanket for the last 60+ years. It has a Shin gunto tsuka and a
> > older
> > > appearing Kyo-sukashi tsuba. The blade is a bit "rough" but still
> > has
> > > very visible hada. The hamon appears to be Suguha for the most
> > part.
> > > The hada is very prominant, it seems to be a Itame/Mokume mix with
> > > Masame near the ha. The Masame hada also can be clearly seen
> > through
> > > the kissaki. The sword is unsigned with a osujikai yasurime. The
> > > nakago condition appears ( a guess ) approx. 1800-1860. I'm
> > thinking
> > > a late Edo copy of an Koto Yamato. Nagasa 65cm, machi width 3.1
> > cm,
> > > yokote 2.1 cm, sori 1.5 cm. Do these characteristics suggest to
> > > anyone a particular Shinshinto School, Smith or Province. I know
> > it
> > > would be difficult with or without blade in hand, but any advice
> > or
> > > information would be appreciated. Thanks.....
> > >
> >
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Interesting sword
messages.msgSnippet: Ricky - ... All of this makes me think ko-to and not at all shinshin-to work. I wonder if your sword s nakago is simply well preserved, making you think it is
messages.messageBody:
Ricky -

>The hada is very prominant, it seems to be a Itame/Mokume mix with Masame near the ha. The Masame hada also can be >clearly seen through the kissaki...O-sugikai yasurime...suguha...

All of this makes me think ko-to and not at all shinshin-to work. I wonder if your sword's nakago is simply well preserved, making you think it is "newer" than it really is. Anytime I see a masame running along the ha it makes me think "early" and starts me looking for further clues. The sword is relatively short; is the nakago original (ubu) or could it be O-suriage? The mention of O-sugikai yasurime makes me think it is ubu, unsigned. It still makes me think ko-to with Yamato characteristic; sue-Tegai perhaps? You do not mention sori; I'm curious what this is telling you. Any photos available???

Ron
STL



----- Original Message -----
From: dwmac2000
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, November 13, 2006 11:59 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Interesting sword



Ricky,

Definitely appreciate the information! I will research your
suggestions. There does seem to be a spot or two of ayasugi. The sword
seems to have a hada simular to koto Yamato Taima and Shikkake both.
Sure wish the nakago appeared 500 yrs. older. None the less, still a
good research project.

Thanks Again,

Dave
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ricky" <fairgreen00@...> wrote:
>
> Lots of possibilites based on your description. Off the top of a
> newbie's head: Naminohira, Kunikane, outside possibility of Gassan
> if you happen to see any spots of ayasugi hada. Hope this points you
> in the right direction.
>
> Ricky
>
>

> wrote:
> >
> > Hello, Recently purchased a sword which was in a closet wrapped
> in a

> older
> > appearing Kyo-sukashi tsuba. The blade is a bit "rough" but still
> has
> > very visible hada. The hamon appears to be Suguha for the most
> part.
> > The hada is very prominant, it seems to be a Itame/Mokume mix with
> > Masame near the ha. The Masame hada also can be clearly seen
> through
> > the kissaki. The sword is unsigned with a osujikai yasurime. The
> > nakago condition appears ( a guess ) approx. 1800-1860. I'm

> > a late Edo copy of an Koto Yamato. Nagasa 65cm, machi width 3.1
> cm,
> > yokote 2.1 cm, sori 1.5 cm. Do these characteristics suggest to
> > anyone a particular Shinshinto School, Smith or Province. I know
> it
> > would be difficult with or without blade in hand, but any advice
> or
> > information would be appreciated. Thanks.....
> >
>

messages.msgSnippet: Lots of possibilites based on your description. Off the top of a newbie s head: Naminohira, Kunikane, outside possibility of Gassan if you happen to see any
messages.messageBody:
Lots of possibilites based on your description. Off the top of a
newbie's head: Naminohira, Kunikane, outside possibility of Gassan
if you happen to see any spots of ayasugi hada. Hope this points you
in the right direction.

Ricky

messages.subject: Interesting sword
messages.msgSnippet: Hello,  Recently purchased a sword which was in a closet wrapped in a blanket for the last 60+ years.  It has a Shin gunto tsuka and a older appearing
messages.messageBody:
Hello, Recently purchased a sword which was in a closet wrapped in a
blanket for the last 60+ years. It has a Shin gunto tsuka and a older
appearing Kyo-sukashi tsuba. The blade is a bit "rough" but still has
very visible hada. The hamon appears to be Suguha for the most part.
The hada is very prominant, it seems to be a Itame/Mokume mix with
Masame near the ha. The Masame hada also can be clearly seen through
the kissaki. The sword is unsigned with a osujikai yasurime. The
nakago condition appears ( a guess ) approx. 1800-1860. I'm thinking
a late Edo copy of an Koto Yamato. Nagasa 65cm, machi width 3.1 cm,
yokote 2.1 cm, sori 1.5 cm. Do these characteristics suggest to
anyone a particular Shinshinto School, Smith or Province. I know it
would be difficult with or without blade in hand, but any advice or
information would be appreciated. Thanks.....
